<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 813, 89]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the cooling of water in different sized beakers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 260, 120]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 351, 920, 384]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 382, 589, 400]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 413, 920, 446]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 444, 920, 477]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 490, 547, 509]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 798, 89]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the refraction of light by a transparent block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 85, 828, 103]]<|/det|>
You will determine a quantity known as the refractive index of the material of the block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 117, 475, 135]]<|/det|>
Use the separate ray-trace sheet provided.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 149, 435, 166]]<|/det|>
You may refer to Fig. 3.1 for guidance.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 173, 888, 648]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 660, 533, 678]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 692, 146, 710]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 692, 920, 742]]<|/det|>
Place the transparent block approximately in the centre of the ray-trace sheet. Carefully draw round the block and label the corners \(\mathbf{A}\) , \(\mathbf{B}\) , \(\mathbf{C}\) and \(\mathbf{D}\) as indicated by Fig. 3.1. Remove the block from the ray-trace sheet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 753, 920, 787]]<|/det|>
Draw a normal to line \(\mathbf{AB}\) at a point \(\mathbf{N}\), \(2\mathrm{cm}\) from \(\mathbf{A}\). Extend the normal downwards until it crosses the line \(\mathbf{CD}\). Label the point at which it crosses \(\mathbf{CD}\) with the letter \(\mathbf{F}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 800, 897, 818]]<|/det|>
Draw a line \(\mathbf{NE}\), as indicated by Fig. 3.1, \(7\mathrm{cm}\) long and at an angle \(\theta_{1} = 15^{\circ}\) to the normal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[893, 816, 920, 833]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 148, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 616, 88]]<|/det|>
Replace the block in exactly the same position as in (a).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 866, 135]]<|/det|>
Place two pins \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) on line **NE**, a suitable distance apart for accurate ray tracing. Mark with crosses and label the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 147, 920, 199]]<|/det|>
View the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) through the block, from the direction indicated by the eye in Fig. 3.1. Place two pins \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) so that pins \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) all appear exactly one behind the other.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 197, 609, 214]]<|/det|>
Mark with crosses and label the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 227, 589, 244]]<|/det|>
Remove the block and pins from the ray-trace sheet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 257, 712, 274]]<|/det|>
Draw a straight line through \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\). Extend this line to cross **NF**.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 273, 920, 306]]<|/det|>
Label the point at which this line meets **NF** with the letter **G**. Label the point at which this line crosses **CD** with the letter **H**.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 306, 920, 323]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 335, 146, 352]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 335, 480, 352]]<|/det|>
Join points \(\mathbf{H}\) and \(\mathbf{N}\) with a straight line.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 365, 425, 382]]<|/det|>
Measure the length \(a\) of line \(\mathbf{HN}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 380, 920, 397]]<|/det|>
<form>a = ............................................................ $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 411, 425, 428]]<|/det|>
Measure the length \(b\) of line \(\mathbf{HG}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 426, 920, 443]]<|/det|>
<form>b = ............................................................ $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 456, 710, 483]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 489, 920, 505]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 583, 848, 600]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 676, 920, 693]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 195, 861, 229]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number on your ray-trace sheet. Tie your ray-trace sheet into this Booklet between pages 8 and 9.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 774, 90]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the speed of a small trolley moving down a sloping ramp.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 920, 136]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment which will enable him to compare the effect of different angles of slope on the average speed of the trolley between points on the ramp.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 149, 551, 167]]<|/det|>
Average speed can be calculated from the equation:

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 186, 771, 217]]<|/det|>
\[\text{average speed} = \frac{\text{distance}}{\text{time}}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 226, 395, 244]]<|/det|>
The apparatus available includes:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 257, 798, 274]]<|/det|>
· a long ramp with a support that enables it to be set at different angles of slope

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 273, 277, 291]]<|/det|>
· a small trolley.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 304, 470, 321]]<|/det|>
You are **not** required to do the experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 335, 225, 352]]<|/det|>
In your plan:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 365, 457, 383]]<|/det|>
· list any additional apparatus needed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 397, 918, 431]]<|/det|>
· explain briefly how to do the experiment, including how to take the measurements so that the average speed can be determined

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 444, 831, 462]]<|/det|>
· suggest a possible source of inaccuracy even if the method is carried out carefully

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 475, 487, 492]]<|/det|>
· state the key variables to keep constant

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 505, 920, 540]]<|/det|>
· draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how to display the readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 553, 604, 570]]<|/det|>
· explain how to use the readings to reach a conclusion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 583, 576, 601]]<|/det|>
You may draw a diagram if it helps to explain your plan.
